WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects the* commons of Ireland in Parliament asserabled, being highly ferifible of the inestimable blellings we enjoy under your Majesty's mild and auspicious reign, and desirous to the utmost of our power to support your Majesty's government with honour, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that as a further supply to your Majesty a sum not exceeding two hundred and sixty five thousand pounds shall be raised by granting life annuities or interest at the rate of six pounds per annum with benefit of survivorship s and for that purpose be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons it this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That if any person or persons, your Majesty's natural born subjects or foreigners, shall within the several times and in manner herein after particularly mentioned pay into his Majesty's treasury in Ireland any sum or sums of money, not exceeding in the whole the said sum of two hundred and sixty five thousand pounds, to be subscribed by them in sums of one hundred pounds each, there shall be paid to such person or persons so paying and advancing the same respectively, their executors, administrators, or assigns, or to the person or persons legally authorized by them to receive the same, ' by the hands of the vice treasurer or vice treasurers, paymaster or receiver general, his or their deputy or deputies, annuities of six pounds per annum for each and every hundred pounds so fubforibed and paid for and during the lives of the persons to be nominated by the persons subscribrng and paying the said sum and sums respectively, together with such additional interest as shall accrue by survivorftiip in manner herein after provided; And to the intent and purpose that all deceits in receiving any annuity or annuities as aforesaid may be prevented, and that the full advantage of survivorship may be bad, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all and every subscriber and subscribers, his, her, or their executors, administrators, or assigns, upon their demanding any half yearly payment of his, her, or their respective annuities, Unless the nominee appear in person at the time of demanding such annuity, shall, whenever the vice treasurer or vice treasurers, or paymaster general, his or theii deputy or deputies shall think proper to demand the same, produce a certificate of the life of his, her, or their respective nominee, signed by the minister or in his absence by the curate of the parish, where such nominee shall be then living, upon the day when the said half yearly payment shall become due; if such nominee shall be then residing in the kingdom of Ireland; which certificate the said minister or curate is hereby required to make without fee or reward; and the said certificate shall be filed in the said office of the vice treasurer or vice treasurers, paymaster or receiver general, his or their deputy or deputies, who are hereby authorized and required, whenever he or they shall find it necessary, to examine upon oath (which oath he or they are hereby impowered to administer) any person entitled to an annuity, or any other person whatsoever, touching the existence of any nominee or nominees.

VII. VII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall continue until the twenty fifth day of December, which shall be in the year one thousand seven hundred and seventy five, and no longer.

CHAP. XII.

An Act for the better and more certain Valuation of Houses in Counties of Cities and Counties of Towns.

WHEREAS a doubt hath arisen, whether all build* ings for charitable purposes, and other publick buildings in counties of cities and counties of towns, are not*'

liable to be valued and charged with a proportion of taxes and rates under the Several acts of Parliament, made for the valuation of houses: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That Publick build-no hospitals, publick infirmaries, alms-houses, charity ings uot includ-schools, publick work-houses, custom houses, or the offices appurtenant thereto, and that no publick exchanges, may- &c5

That it be agreed between the subscribers to the a» herein, grand canal and the city of Dublin^ that ia consideration of

The thirteenth and fourteenth Years of George III. of the subscribers supplying the city with such a quantity oF water, hereafter to be ascertained, as shall amply supply the several inhabitants thereof, the city shall pay to the said subscribers ten per cent. upon the gross produce of the revenue, that shall arise to the city from the sale of the said water; the payment of the said ten per cent. not to commence 'till the first day of May, one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix; and the subscribers also engaging that they shall not erect any works upon the navigation, which shall cause any impurity in the water, so as to render it unfit for life." Resolved, That it be also agreed, that the subscribers on their part, and the city on theirs, shall use their bed endeavours to obtain an act of parliament for ratifying the above agreement as soon as possible; therefore be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said agreement and every part thereof shall stand ratified and confirmed.

And whereas many inconveniencies and mischiefs have frequently arisen and daily arise to suitors and others, by reason that persons, who have been legally admitted attornies of the courts, but who afterwards resided intirely or for the moll part in the country, do there in like manner take apprentices from amongst the lower class of the

XXVIII. And be it farther enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any collector, appointed by the grand jury of any county, shall happen to die, before he shall have collected the publick money, it shall be lawful for the justices of the peace of such county at the quarter-sessions, or any ac^ournment thereof, to appoint another fit and proper person to collect the publick money in the place of such collector deceased upon his giving sufficient security to perform the requisites aforesaid, until a collector shall be appointed by the grand jury of such county aforesaid.

XXIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be lawful for any person, who shall think himself or herself aggrieved by the presentment of any grand jury, to enter one or more traverse or traverses in open court to such presentment; which traverse or traverses shall be tried immediately, or at the next assizes.

XXX. Provided always, That such traverse may be tried upon the entry of any presentment in the crown boojt, and the traverse taken thereto, without making up any record for the purpose, so that such entry in the crown book be sufficient in substance, though it may be defective in point of form. II. The fifteenth andsixteenth Years of George III.

The Fifteenth and Sixteenth Years of GEORGE III. CHAP. It.

17* A.D.

an Act for granting Annuities in the Manner therein provided to such Persons as shall voluntarily subscribe towards the ratfing a Sum not exceeding the Sum of one hundred and seventy five thousand Pounds.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ireland in Parliament assembled, being highly fenlible of the inestimable blefiings we enjoy under your Majesty's mild and auspicious reign, and desirous to the utmost of our power to support your Majesty's government with honour, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that as a further supply to your Majesty a sum, not exceeding one hundred and seventy five thousand pounds, shall be raised by granting life annuities, or intered, at the rate of six pounds per annum, with benefit of survivorship: and for that purpose be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that if any person or persons, his Majesty's natural born subjects, or foreigners, shall within the several times, and in manner herein after particularly mentioned, pay into his Majesty's treasury in Ireland any sum or sums of money, not exceeding in the whole the said sum of one hundred and seventy five thousand pounds, to be subscribed by them in sums of one hundred pounds each, there shall be paid to such person or persons so paying or advancing the same respectively, their executors, administrators, or assigns, or to the person or persons legally authorized by them to receive the same, by the hands of the vice treasurer or vice treasurers, paymaster or receiver general, his or their deputy pr deputies, annuities of six pounds per annum for each and every hundred pounds so subscribed and paid for and during the lives of the persons to be nominated by the persons subscribing and paying the said sum and sums respectively, together with such additional intered as shall accrue by survivorship, in manner herein after provided; and that the said annuities shall commence from the twenty fifth day of December, one thousand seven hundred and seventy five, and shall be paid half yearly in equal portions on every twenty fourth day of June and twenty fifth day of December in every year.

CHAP. XIV.

an Act for repealing an Act made in the thirteenth and fourteenth Years of the Reign of his frejent Majesty, entitled.

An Act to explain and amend An Act made in the third Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the second, entitled. An Act for the better keeping Churches in Repair, and for other Purposes.

WHEREAS the parishioners of several parishes in this kingdom have neglected or refused to make pmvi- 3> c IO# TCm fion at their respective vestries for the repairs of the churches pealed, extendU or chapels within their respective parishes, and to defray the in£to P411*1*8 necessary charges for the performance of divine service there-in, to the disgrace and discouragement of the established religion: and whereas an act made in the thirteenth and fourteenth years of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An Act to explain casd amend an act made in the third year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the second, entitled, An act for the better keeping churches in repair, was intended to remedy said abuses \ but the provisions made by the said act extend as well to those parishes, in which there had been no such default, as to those in which there had: and whereas it is not reasonable, that the innocent Should be confounded with the guilty; be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembcted, and by the authority of the same, that the said recited act of the last session, and every thing therein contained, be from henceforth repealed.

II. And to the end that Parliament may be informed of A fpccjai^. the state and condition of the several churches and chapels turn to both in this kingdom, and of the conduct of the parishioners houses by iftof thereof with respect to the particulars herein before menti- as

oned, in order that an adequate remedy may be provided for the reformation of such abuses, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the deans, archdeacons, prebendaries, and all redors, vicars, and perpetual Curates within this kingdom, shall upon the belt information make a special return to the clerks of both houses of Parliament on or before the first day of the next session of Parliament of the true, state, age, and condition of their respective parish churches and chapels, and whether they are safe and fit for

'v the

The ffieenth and Jixteenth Yean of George III. the resort of the parishioners to have divine service performed therein, and whether the said churches and chapels respectively have been from time to time provided with such useful and decent requisites, as are necessary for the due celebration of the sacrament, and the regular performance of divine service according to the rites and ceremonies of the church of Ireland, and whether any taxes, and to what amount, have been applied for or levied for five years previous to the first day of December, one thousand seven hundred and seventy five, to answer the purposes aforesaid.

CHAP. XVI.

An Act for better regulating the Elections of Members to serve in Parliament.

WHEREAS the idleness and dissipation, caused by the length of time frequently spent in the poll at elections for members to serve in Parliament, are productive of many evils, and are of dangerous tendency to the freedom of election: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That in all cases where the election cannot be determined upon view, and a poll shall be demanded, the sheriff or other returning officer or officers on every election, whenever it shall appear, that upon the lall or any former election the number of eledors have exceeded four hundred, shall before the commencement of the poll appoint one deputy to take the poll under him or them, at the same time, and in the same court house, or if there shall not be convenient room therein, in the ne'treft convenient place; and shall not during such election adjourn for any longer time than fiom day to

IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons shall violently and outrage* ously disturb the courts or other assembly duly holdert for the election of a member or members to serve in Parliament, or interrupt the proceeding of the prill, such diflur-bance or riot shall not be any excuse to the returning officer, nor afford him any pretence for doling the poll; or making a return, but the court or other such assembly as aforesaid shall thereupon be adjourned for some convenient time, as the occasion may require; and, if it Should be necessary, shall be further continued by adjournment from time to time, till such disturbance shall have ceased, \vhen such returning officer Hi all return, and again proceed on taking the poll; and every person, who shall be convicted of having violently and outrageously disturbed the court so as to interrupt the proceeding of the poll, or of having wilfully effaced, obliterated, tom, altered, or dellroyed the whole or any part of the poll book of the returning officer, or his deputy, whereon any thing relative to the said election hath been entered, or of having forcibly or fraudulently taken or secreted the same, or any fitch part thereof, or the writ or precept for holding such election, he shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and be transported for seven years to some one of his Majesty's plantations abroad.

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no sheriff or other returning officer or officers shall upon any pretence whatsoever return more than the number of persons, he dull by his writ or precept be required to return; and that in case of an equality of voices for any two of more candidates upon the close of the poll he shall be 2t liberty to give his calling voice, whether otherwise legally qualified to vote or not at such election; and if any ffieriff or returning officer shall return more than the number of persons, lie shall by his writ or precept be directed to return, and shall be convicted thereof in any of his Ida-jesty's courts of record, he shall forfeit and lose the sum of two thousand pounds, to the person who shall have prosecut* ed him to conviction; and he shall be adjudged and he is hereby declared to be incapable of ever after voting at any election for members to serve in Parliament.

CHAP. XXIII.

*An Act for the Relief of the Out Pensioners of the Hof pit al of King Charles the Second for antient and maimed Officers find Soldiers, of the Army of Ireland'

WHEREAS the out pensioners of the hospital of To prevent ^*King Charles the second, for antient and maimed Officers and soldiers of the army of Ireland, have of late

suffered great impositions and distresses from the fraudulent practices of money lenders, from whom the said outpen-sioners frequently take up money on terms many times most u furious and oppressive: for the prevention of all which &bufes and mischiefs, be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all assignments, bargains, sales, contrafts, orders, letters, or powers of attorney, irrevocable, or conveying intered, and agreements or fecufities whatsoever, made by any out pensioner, for, upon, or in respect of any sum or sums of money due, or to become due, for or on account of the penijon of the said hospital, to such out pensioners as have Been or shall be admitted thereunto, shall from and after the twenty fourth day of June, in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy fix, be absolutely null and void to all intents and purposes.

An Act to amend and continue an Act passed in the thirteenth and fourteenth Years of his present Majesty, entitled. Ax AB for the better Regulation of the baking Trade in the at) of Dublin^ and for other Purposes.

The seventeenth and eighteenth Years of George III.

CHAP. XIX.

an Act for the better Preservation of Fish in Rivers, Lakes, and Inland Waters.

361 A.D.

1777-8.

WHEREAS through a defect of the laws now in being there is not a sufficient provision made against taking and destroying fish in rivers, lakes, and inland waters; whereby many persons are tempted to neglect their trades and other occupations, and to use moil destructive means of catching and killing them by damning rivers, and taking and destroying the breeding fish with nets, spears, gins, and other engines, whereby, if longer permitted, the several species of such fish are likely to be utterly annihilated in most parts of this kingdom, and his Majesty's peaceable and industrious subjects are exposed to imminent danger of having their houses, offices, and haggards set on fire by the dangerous practice of fishing at night by lights 5 for remedy* whereof, be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and ^fter the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight, no person or persons whatsoever, not qualified, except as herein mentioned, shall have, keep, or use any ney, leape, pifehe, gaff, spear, or lyfter, or other engine, boat or curragh, (angling rods with lines and hooks excepted) other than the makers or fellers thereof, and the owners of rivers or of parts of rivers for the time being; and that it shall and may be lawful for any owner of any river or fishery, or of part of a river or fishery, and every person or persons by any owner or owners of any river or fishery, or of any part of a river or fishery, for that purpose appointed, to seize, detain, and keep to his and their own use and uses all and every such cott, boat, curragh, or float, nett, leape, pifehe, gaff, spear, or lyfter, and other engine for catching fish, except as before excepted, which he or they shall find used or laid, or in the custody or possession of any person or persons whatsoever, not qualified as herein mentioned, fishing in any river, or inland fishery, lake, or inland water whatsoever, without the consent of the owner or owners thereof given under their hand; and for any person or persons whatsoever, being thereunto authorized by warrant under the hand and seal of any justice of the peace of the same county, or county of the city or town, in the day time to search the houses, outhouses, or Ot&cr places, of any person hereby prohibited to have, keep,

or

None, unless qualified, shall keep, or use net, engine, Ac. (angling rods excepted) save makers or fellers, and owners of rivers, Ac. as herein.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons after the said twenty-fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and feveo-ty-eight, shall lull, take, or dellroy, any carp, tench, bream, roach, perch, eel, pike, trout, cray fish, or any other

III. And in order to deter idle and disorderly persons

from fishing by night with lights, boats, curraghs, (pears, snares, netts, gins, or any engine whatsoever, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any person whatsoever shall be convicted on the oathof one credible witftefsbefore any jufficeof the peace of the county or jurisdiction, where the offence shall be committed, of fishing by night with lights, or boats, cur-raghs, cotta, or floats, with spears, netts, fnarcs, gins, or any engine whatsoever, (except with rods and lines) such person so convicted shall forfeit any sum not more than five pounds, nor less than two pounds, at the discretion of such justice, to be levied off the goods and chattles of such offender by the warrant of the said justices, which forfeiture shall be paid to the informer or prosecutor x and in case ao diffrefs shall be found, such offender shall be committed to the county gaol by such justice, there to remain without bail or main-prize any time not exceeding six calendar months, nor less than three calendar months, as his committal by such justice shall specify. VII. Whereas the fisheries of Loughneagh, Lougherne, and of other loughs, and of the several rivers flowing thereto and therefrom, are greatly injured by large draught nets with ground ropes and Ankers drawn therein from the twenty-fifth day of August to the twenty-fifth day of December, by persons pretending to fish for pollens: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall not be lawful for any person or persons on any pretence whatsoever to fish with draught or other nets, in the said loughs or rivers, or any of them, or in any of the bays thereof from the twelfth day of August until the first day of January in any year; and if any person or persons shall herein offend, and be thereof convicted by the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses before any justice of the peace, such person or persons shall forfeit the nets and other implements used by him, and also five pounds for every such offence; which sum the said justice of the peace is hereby impowered to levy by his warrant; and for want of distress for this purpose shall commit tach of the offenders to prison for anytime not exceeding six months

VIII. And whereas great quantities of salmon fry are obflru&ed from returning to the sea, and destroyed at the tads of mill-firearm by means of dams and other obstructions made across the dreams under the water wheels of said mills, which cannot be done without the consent or knowledge of the proprietors, millers, or principal acting persons therein: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any such dams or obstructions are dispovered, or any implement or instrument used at said places to qbftru& or destroy the salmon fry, the proprietor, miller, or principal acting person of such mill, where such dams or obfiructions are made, or such implements found, shall on proof thereof by one or more credible witness or witnesses before any justice of the peace forfeit the sum of five pounds, to be recovered in such manner as the other penalties ip this arc rp-coverable.

X. A nd whereas there is a very pernicious practice all

round the wcfl and north well coasts of Ireland of tanning Sea fish nets -or barking of nets, which practice is not only of little effect "d lines cured in regard to the first intention of preferying said net9, but*

on the contrary of infinite detriment to the growth of young trees, and deilruction of plantations, through the villainous-practice of dripping trees merely for the bark thereof in order to tan or bark nets for the herring, salmon, and other fisheries, notwithstanding there is a much more efficacious method of curing of nets, less expensive, and in no lhape detrimental to plantations, by curing said nets with tar and, oil, which nets so cured may lie for a month wet without getting damage, whereas bark-cured nets mull be dried daily, or they will rot: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all nets for taking herrings, salmon, or any sea fish, and all fishing lines cured after the passing of this act, shall be cured with tar and oil, and not barked or tanned, under penalty of the forfeiture of all such nets to the informer upon conviction before a justice of the peace.

CHAP. XXI.

An Act to explain and amend an Act passed in the third Year of the Reign of hie present Majesty, entitled, An Act for the better Regulation of the Linen and Hempen Manufactures.

WH E& E A S bjr an act passed in the third year of Amended the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act x9» 20 ° 3-Jar the better regulation of the linen and hempen manufactures, q

it is amongst other things enacted, That from and after the c.^'

fit ft day of August, one thousand seven hundred and sixty four, every person who shall fell and deliver to any one buyer at one time four or more pecks or any larger quantity or parcel of flax seed or hemp feed for sowing, or in order to be sown, shall together with every such parcel delivered to the buyer in writing a certificate subscribed by such person, eXpressing truly the quantity and price of the feed so fold, and that the same was so fold in order to be sown, and, if the same shall be a foreign production, the port from whence the same was imported, and the name of the country where it grew, and the year of its growth, and, if such feed shall be of the produce of this kingdom, the name of the country where it grew, and the year of its growth, upon pain of forfeiting such feed as shall be so fold without such certificate as aforesaid, or the value or price thereof, and also the sum of three pounds for every hogshead thereof, and so in proportion for any lesser quantity*; and if any such flax seed or hemp feed shall be of a different growth or age, from what shall be expressed in such certificate, the person that shall have fold the same, shall forfeit the price or full value thereof to the person that shall have bought the same; and that from and after the said first day of August, ohe thousand seven hundred and sixty-four, no person or persons shall fell, or offer to fell, or expose to sale, any bad, mixed, or damnified flax seed or hemp feed for sowing, or in order to be sown, upon pain of forfeiting such feed or the value thereof, and also the sum of three pounds sterling for every hogshead of such feed, and so in proportion for any lesser quantity: and whereas the said recited clauses have been attended with inconvenience to the publick, and it is found expedient to repeal the same; be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice fend content of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of June next the said claui'es, and every thing therein contained, Audi be repealed and made null and void.

dn si8 to explain the Statute of the twenty-eighth Tear of Henry the Eighth, entitled, The sM of Faculties.

WHEREAS doubts have arisen, whether a dignity, ^V canonry, or prebend in a cathedral church be compatible with any other benefice, or may be holden together with the same without first obtaining a dispensation for such purpose: And whereas according to the practice in this kingdom many benefices are in fast so holden, and the titles thereunto respectively are consequently expo fed to such doubts: in remedy wheredf, be it enacted by the King*i most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all persons, who were in the aftnal possessioo of any dignity, canonry, or prebend in a cathedral church, together with any other benefice or benefices, on or before the twenty-fifth day of December last, may hold, possess, and enjoy the lame in like manner, as if a dispensation had been regularly and in due time obtained for holding the same: any law or ufagfe to the contrary hereof in any wise notwithstanding.

II. Provided, That nothing herein contained shall extend to or affect any act, matter, or thing done, or suit commenced, before the said twenty-fifth day of December last for voiding any ecclesiastical benefice, dignity, canonnV or prebend ou account of such incompatibility as aforesaid.

LXVIII. Whereas several frauds have been committed in the trade and employment of making playing cards, whereby not only the payment of the duties, to which playing cards are subject, is evaded, but the fair trader materially prejudiced: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the twenty fourth day of August, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, it shall and may be lawful to and for the chief commissionera of his Majesty's revenue, or any three of them, to issue and grant a licence or licences to such person or persons, as they shall think proper, for the making of playing, blank, and message cards for any term not exceeding three years from the time of granting such licence or licences; and if any mide without person or persons shall after the first day of August one thousand seven hundred and eighty exercise or carry on the tc, xodL trade or employment of making any playing, blank, or Icc. message cards, without such licenoe or licences first had and obtained, the person or persons so offending shall for every such offence forfeit the fun^of one hundred pounds, together with all such cards, and all such materials and implements used in the making of cards, as shall be found in his, her, pr their possession; all which cards, materials, and implements shall and may be seized, carried away, and lodged in the next excise office by such revenue officer or officers, as shall discover and find the same.

Ain A3 to prevent Combinations, and for the further Encouragement of Trade.

IN order to fecu're to every man the full 'enjoyment of Combinati-that property he has in his own labour, to find employ- ons amoDgmaf-tnent for th&industrioUs, and bread for the poor, and to ex- ters or |?ur"cI" tend throughout this ancient kingdom all the benefits of nu, fances and free trade, be it eiia&ed and declared by the King's most ought to be excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the fapprefied. Lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that all and every fort of combinations in trade as well among master manufacturers as amoog journeymen are publick nuisances, and ought to be suppressed; and that it is the duty of all sheriffs, mayors, justices of the peace, constables, and other civil magistrates and officers, to oppose and: prosecute to conviction and punishment all persons, who shall henceforth be concerned in the same.

III. And whereas great expence and injury has arisen to the creditors of bankrupts by the debtors of bank? opts not paying their debts to the assignees: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the debtor of every bankrupt, who shall not pay his, her, or their debts to the assignee or assignees of each commission, within three months after issuing the commission, and demand made by or on behalf of such assignee or assignees, (Kali be obliged to pay over and above their said debt interest for the same at the rate of six pounds per centum per annum from the time of such demand made.

IV. IV. And whereas it is expedient, that the grand jury of the county of Cork shall have power to present a greater yearly sum for the treasurer of the said county, than they by the laws now in force are impowered to do, the said county being of a large extent, and requiring a treasurer very conversant in accdKts, and who can give security for the large sums nc^eflary to be raised in that county; be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty-fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and* eighty the grand jury at the affixes to be held for the said county from time- to time shall fyare power, if they think fit, to make preferments in the usual manner for raising any sum not exceeding fifty pounds a year for the treasurer of the said county for the time being, over and above the sums which the grand jury of the said county is impowered by the laws now in force to present for such treasurer, and the judges at such affizea shall and may confirm the said presentment.

V. And be it further erta&tfd by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed, adjudged, and taken to be a publick act, and be judicially taken notice of as such by all judges, justices, and all other persons whatsoever, without specially pleading the same.

XI.
